back: Given a square $n \times n$ matrix $\mathbf{M}$, a non-zero $n$-vector $\mathbf{u}$ is an eigenvector of $\mathbf{M}$ if there exists a constant $\lambda$ such that \begin{equation} \mathbf{Mu} = \lambda \mathbf{u}. \end{equation}
Given a square $n \times n$ matrix $\mathbf{M}$, a constant $\lambda$ is an eigenvalue of $\mathbf{M}$ if there exists a non-zero vector $\mathbf{u}$ such that \[ \mathbf{Mu} = \lambda \mathbf{u}. \]
For a square matrix \(\mathbf{M}\), the modal matrix is a matrix whose columns are the unit eigenvectors of \(\mathbf{M}\).
